topics.content: The chapter introduces the magnetic and heating effects of electricity through a series of 'Probe and ponder' questions and a narrative about a science exhibition. Key questions raised include how to detect current without a lamp, the creation of temporary magnets, heat generation in electrical appliances, and identifying dead cells. The introductory story highlights a lifting electromagnet model, sparking curiosity about the link between electricity and magnetism.

This section explains that an electric current flowing through a conductor produces a magnetic field around it. This is demonstrated through Activity 4.1, where a current-carrying wire deflects a magnetic compass needle. The text defines a magnetic field as the region around a magnet or current-carrying wire where its magnetic effect can be felt. It also credits scientist Hans Christian Oersted for discovering this phenomenon in 1820, noting its practical applications in devices like electric bells and motors.

Electromagnets are current-carrying coils that behave as magnets. Activities 4.2 and 4.3 demonstrate how to create electromagnets using a coil of wire wrapped around an iron nail and connected to a cell. The experiments show that the electromagnet attracts iron clips when current flows and loses its magnetism when the current stops. Inserting an iron nail into the coil makes it a stronger magnet. The text explains that electromagnets have poles like bar magnets, which can be determined using a magnetic compass and can be reversed by changing the direction of the current. The strength of an electromagnet can be increased by increasing the electric current or the number of turns in the coil. Lifting electromagnets are strong electromagnets used in cranes to move heavy iron/steel objects, controlled by switching the current on and off. The Earth's magnetic field, generated by the movement of liquid iron in its core, is also mentioned as a natural magnet with implications for navigation and protection.

This section explains that when electric current flows through a conductor, it gets heated due to the conductor's resistance to the flow of current. This phenomenon is called the heating effect of electric current. Activity 4.5 demonstrates this using a nichrome wire, which heats up when current passes through it. The intensity of heating depends on the current, material, thickness, length of the wire, and duration of current flow. Many household appliances like electric heaters, irons, kettles, and hair dryers work on this principle, utilizing a 'heating element'. The text also discusses safety precautions related to overheating in electrical connections and the use of safety devices.

topics.topic: Generation of Electricity in Cells and Batteries
topics.content: Cells and batteries generate electricity through chemical reactions. The chapter introduces the Voltaic cell (also known as Galvanic cell), which uses two different metal plates (electrodes) partially dipped in an electrolyte (a weak acid or salt solution) to produce electricity. Chemical reactions cause the cell to work, and it becomes 'dead' when the chemicals are used up. The text also briefly mentions dry cells, where the electrolyte is a moist paste, and rechargeable batteries, which can be reused multiple times. The invention of the first battery by Alessandro Volta and Luigi Galvani is highlighted.

topics.topic: Types of Electric Cells and Batteries
topics.content: The chapter details different types of electric cells and batteries. The Voltaic cell is described as an early type, with an example of constructing a lemon cell using copper wires, iron nails, and lemon juice as the electrolyte. Dry cells are presented as more convenient for everyday use, featuring a zinc container as the negative terminal and a carbon rod as the positive terminal, with a paste-like electrolyte. Rechargeable batteries are emphasized for their reusability and environmental benefits, with examples of their use in laptops, mobile phones, vehicles, and inverters. Modern advancements like lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries and future developments like solid-state batteries are also mentioned.
